newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian bonds get boost from Greenspan.
newsitem.headline: Australian bonds get boost from Greenspan.

text.p: *Australian bond yields set new lows for the day as U.S. Treasuries extended Thursday's rally after comments by Fed Chairman Greenspan.
*Local focus now pinned on next Tuesday's budget.
Australian bond yields set new lows for the day as U.S. Treasuries extended Thursday's rally on short-covering following comments by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan.
"It's clear that Greenspan is intent on smacking inflation, and that's got to be good for the bond market," one trader said.
Greenspan said in New York that he expects economic growth to slow later this year and into next, but also warned that the central bank would need to act if this does note prove the case.
The Fed Chairman also said that there were scant signs now of an imminent resurgence of inflation.

Prior to Greenspan's comments the morning session had been a fairly low key affair as the market consolidated this week's whippy price action, particularly after Reserve Bank governor Ian Macfarlane ruled out a further easing in monetary policy.
There was no data released on Friday apart from March private sector credit, which rose 0.7 percent, leaving the market to focus on next Tuesday's Federal budget.
Some economists are predicting a headline surplus of up to A$10 billion for 1997/98, which could see little or no conventional bond supply in the fiscal year.

Local debt continued to outpace the U.S. market, despite its strength in Tokyo trading, and further narrowed its margin to Canada, which was undermined by weakness in the Canadian dollar on Thursday. The yield curve flattened again, testing support at 85 basis points on the 3/10-year futures spread.
